52.248-1 Value Engineering. (Jun 2020)
As prescribed in  48.201 , insert the following clause:
Value Engineering (Jun 2020)
(a) General. The Contractor is encouraged to develop, prepare, and submit value engineering change proposals (VECP's) voluntarily. The Contractor 
shall share in any net acquisition savings realized from accepted VECP's, in accordance with the incentive sharing rates in paragraph (f) of this clause.
(b) Definitions.
Acquisition savings, as used in this clause, means savings resulting from the application of a VECP to contracts awarded by the same contracting 
office or its successor for essentially the same unit. Acquisition savings include-
(1) Instant contract savings, which are the net cost reductions on this, the instant contract, and which are equal to the instant unit cost reduction 
multiplied by the number of instant contract units affected by the VECP, less the Contractor's allowable development and implementation costs;
(2) Concurrent contract savings, which are net reductions in the prices of other contracts that are definitized and ongoing at the time the VECP is 
accepted; and
(3) Future contract savings, which are the product of the future unit cost reduction multiplied by the number of future contract units in the sharing 
base. On an instant contract, future contract savings include savings on increases in quantities after VECP acceptance that are due to contract 
modifications, exercise of options, additional orders, and funding of subsequent year requirements on a multiyear contract.
Collateral savings, as used in this clause, means those measurable net reductions resulting from a VECP in the agency's overall projected collateral 
costs, exclusive of acquisition savings, whether or not the acquisition cost changes.
Contracting office includes any contracting office that the acquisition is transferred to, such as another branch of the agency or another agency's office 
that is performing a joint acquisition action.
Contractor's development and implementation costs, as used in this

chunk-d2d8d40270a3bbd784a863a1d87321e8.content:
subsequent year requirements on a multiyear contract.
Collateral savings, as used in this clause, means those measurable net reductions resulting from a VECP in the agency's overall projected collateral 
costs, exclusive of acquisition savings, whether or not the acquisition cost changes.
Contracting office includes any contracting office that the acquisition is transferred to, such as another branch of the agency or another agency's office 
that is performing a joint acquisition action.
Contractor's development and implementation costs, as used in this clause, means those costs the Contractor incurs on a VECP specifically in 
developing, testing, preparing, and submitting the VECP, as well as those costs the Contractor incurs to make the contractual changes required by 
Government acceptance of a VECP.
Future unit cost reduction, as used in this clause, means the instant unit cost reduction adjusted as the Contracting Officer considers necessary for 
projected learning or changes in quantity during the sharing period. It is calculated at the time the VECP is accepted and applies either-
(1) Throughout the sharing period, unless the Contracting Officer decides that recalculation is necessary because conditions are significantly different 
from those previously anticipated; or
(2) To the calculation of a lump-sum payment, which cannot later be revised.
Government costs, as used in this clause, means those agency costs that result directly from developing and implementing the VECP, such as any net W519TC25RA005Page 51 of 86
increases in the cost of testing, operations, maintenance, and logistics support. The term does not include the normal administrative costs of 
processing the VECP or any increase in this contract's cost or price resulting from negative instant contract savings.
Instant contract, as used in this clause, means this contract, under which the VECP is submitted. It does not include increases in quantities after 
acceptance of the VECP that are due to contract modifications, exercise of options, or additional orders. If this is a multiyear contract, the term does 
not include quantities funded after VECP acceptance. If this contract is a fixed-price contract with prospective price redetermination, the term refers 
to the period for which firm prices have been established.
Instant unit cost reduction means the amount of the decrease in unit cost of performance (without deducting any Contractor's development or 
implementation costs) resulting from using the VECP on this, the instant contract. If this is a service contract, the instant unit cost reduction is 
normally equal to the number of hours per line-item task saved by using the VECP on this contract, multiplied by the appropriate contract labor rate.
Negative instant contract savings means the increase in the cost or price of this contract when the acceptance of a VECP results in an excess of the 
Contractor's allowable development and implementation costs over the product of the instant unit cost reduction multiplied by the number of instant 
contract units affected.
Net acquisition savings means total acquisition savings, including instant, concurrent, and future contract savings, less Government costs.
Sharing base, as used in this clause, means the number of affected end items on contracts of the contracting office accepting the VECP.
Sharing period, as used in this clause, means the period beginning with acceptance of the first unit incorporating the VECP and ending at a calendar 
date or event determined by the contracting officer for each VECP.
Unit, as used in this clause, means the item or task to which the Contracting Officer and the Contractor agree the VECP applies.
Value engineering change proposal (VECP) means a proposal that-
(1) Requires a change to this, the instant contract, to implement; and
(2) Results in reducing the overall projected cost to the agency without impairing essential functions or characteristics;provided, that it does not 
involve a change-
(i) In deliverable end item quantities only;
(ii) In research and development (R&D) end items or R&D test quantities that is due solely to results of previous testing under this contract; or
(iii) To the contract type only.
(c) VECP preparation. As a minimum, the Contractor shall include in each VECP the information described in paragraphs (c)(1) through (8) of this 
clause. If the proposed change is affected by contractually required configuration management or similar procedures, the instructions in those 
procedures relating to format, identification, and priority assignment shall govern VECP preparation. The VECP shall include the following:
(1) A description of the difference between the existing contract requirement and the proposed requirement, the comparative advantages and 
disadvantages of each, a justification when an item's function or characteristics are being altered, the effect of the change on the end item's 
performance, and any pertinent objective test data.
(2) A list and analysis of the contract requirements that must be changed if the VECP is accepted, including any suggested specification revisions.
(3) Identification of the unit to which the VECP applies.
(4) A separate, detailed cost estimate for (i) the affected portions of the existing contract requirement and (ii) the VECP. The cost reduction associated 
with the VECP shall take into account the Contractor's allowable development and implementation costs, including any amount attributable to 
subcontracts under the Subcontracts paragraph of this clause.
(5) A description and estimate of costs the Government may incur in implementing the VECP, such as test and evaluation and operating and support 
costs.
(6) A prediction of any effects the proposed change would have on collateral costs to the agency.
(7) A statement of the time by which a contract modification accepting the VECP must be issued in order to achieve the maximum cost reduction, 
noting any effect on the contract completion time or delivery schedule.
(8) Identification of any previous submissions of the VECP, including the dates submitted, the agencies and contract numbers involved, and previous 
Government

chunk-04bf2894f2beedf31145087e97320e9e.content:
and operating and support 
costs.
(6) A prediction of any effects the proposed change would have on collateral costs to the agency.
(7) A statement of the time by which a contract modification accepting the VECP must be issued in order to achieve the maximum cost reduction, 
noting any effect on the contract completion time or delivery schedule.
(8) Identification of any previous submissions of the VECP, including the dates submitted, the agencies and contract numbers involved, and previous 
Government actions, if known.
(d) Submission. The Contractor shall submit VECP's to the Contracting Officer, unless this contract states otherwise. If this contract is administered 
by other than the contracting office, the Contractor shall submit a copy of the VECP simultaneously to the Contracting Officer and to the 
Administrative Contracting Officer.W519TC25RA005Page 52 of 86
(e) Government action.
(1) The Contracting Officer will notify the Contractor of the status of the VECP within 45 calendar days after the contracting office receives it. If 
additional time is required, the Contracting Officer will notify the Contractor within the 45-day period and provide the reason for the delay and the 
expected date of the decision. The Government will process VECP's expeditiously; however, it will not be liable for any delay in acting upon a VECP.
(2) If the VECP is not accepted, the Contracting Officer will notify the Contractor in writing, explaining the reasons for rejection. The Contractor may 
withdraw any VECP, in whole or in part, at any time before it is accepted by the Government. The Contracting Officer may require that the 
Contractor provide written notification before undertaking significant expenditures for VECP effort.
(3) Any VECP may be accepted, in whole or in part, by the Contracting Officer's award of a modification to this contract citing this clause and made 
either before or within a reasonable time after contract performance is completed. Until such a contract modification applies a VECP to this contract, 
the Contractor shall perform in accordance with the existing contract. The decision to accept or reject all or part of any VECP is a unilateral decision 
made solely at the discretion of the Contracting Officer.
(f) Sharing rates. If a VECP is accepted, the Contractor shall share in net acquisition savings according to the percentages shown in the table below. 
The percentage paid the Contractor depends upon-
(1) This contract's type (fixed-price, incentive, or cost-reimbursement);
(2) The sharing arrangement specified in paragraph (a) of this clause (incentive, program requirement, or a combination as delineated in the 
Schedule); and
(3) The source of the savings (the instant contract, or concurrent and future contracts), as follows:
          
                 Contractor's Share of Net Acquisition Savings (Figure in Percent)    
                 Contract Type                 Incentive (Voluntary)                 Program Requirement (Mandatory)  
                                  Instant Contract Rate                 Concurrent and Future Contract Rate                 Instant Contract Rate                 Concurrent and 
Future Contract Rate  
                 Fixed-price (includes fixed-price-award-fee; excludes other fixed-price incentive contracts)                 *50                 *50                 
25                 25  
                 Incentive (fixed-price or cost) (other than award fee)                 (**)                 *50                 (**)                 25  
                 Cost-reimbursement (includes cost-plus-award-fee; excludes other cost-type incentive contracts)                 ***25                 
***25                 15                 15  
                 * The Contracting Office may increase the Contractor's sharing rate to as high as 75 percent for each VECP.  
                 ** Same sharing arrangement as the contract's profit or fee adjustment formula.  
                 *** The Contracting Office may increase the Contractor's sharing rate to as high as 50 percent for each VECP.  
(g) Calculating net acquisition savings.
(1) Acquisition savings are realized when (i) the cost or price is reduced on the instant contract, (ii) reductions are negotiated in concurrent contracts, 
(iii) future contracts are awarded, or (iv) agreement is reached on a lump-sum payment for future contract savings (see paragraph (i)(4) of this clause). 
Net acquisition savings are first realized, and the Contractor shall be paid a share, when Government costs and any negative instant contract savings 
have been fully offset against acquisition savings.
(2) Except in incentive contracts, Government costs and any price or cost increases resulting from negative instant contract savings shall be offset 
against acquisition savings each time such savings are realized until they are fully offset. Then, the Contractor's share is calculated by multiplying net 
acquisition savings by the appropriate Contractor's percentage sharing rate (see paragraph (f) of this clause). Additional Contractor shares of net 
acquisition savings shall be paid to the Contractor at the time realized.
(3) If this is an incentive contract, recovery of Government costs on the instant contract shall be deferred and offset against concurrent and future 
contract savings. The Contractor shall share through the contract incentive structure in savings on the instant contract items affected. Any negative 
instant contract savings shall be added to the target cost or to the target price and ceiling price, and the amount shall be offset against concurrent and 
future contract savings.
(4) If the Government does not receive and accept all items on which it paid the Contractor's share, the Contractor shall reimburse the Government for 
the proportionate share of these payments.
(h) Contract adjustment. The modification accepting the VECP (or a subsequent modification issued as soon as possible after any negotiations are 
completed) shall-
(1) Reduce the contract price or estimated cost by the amount of instant contract savings, unless this is an incentive contract;
(2) When the amount of instant contract savings is negative, increase the contract price, target price and ceiling price, target cost, or estimated

chunk-47e7a3adb451c7514d7deafe285a52ba.content:
the Contractor shall reimburse the Government for 
the proportionate share of these payments.
(h) Contract adjustment. The modification accepting the VECP (or a subsequent modification issued as soon as possible after any negotiations are 
completed) shall-
(1) Reduce the contract price or estimated cost by the amount of instant contract savings, unless this is an incentive contract;
(2) When the amount of instant contract savings is negative, increase the contract price, target price and ceiling price, target cost, or estimated cost by 
that amount;
(3) Specify the Contractor's dollar share per unit on future contracts, or provide the lump-sum payment;
(4) Specify the amount of any Government costs or negative instant contract savings to be offset in determining net acquisition savings realized from 
concurrent or future contract savings; andW519TC25RA005Page 53 of 86
(5) Provide the Contractor's share of any net acquisition savings under the instant contract in accordance with the following:
(i) Fixed-price contracts-add to contract price.
(ii) Cost-reimbursement contracts-add to contract fee.
(i) Concurrent and future contract savings.
(1) Payments of the Contractor's share of concurrent and future contract savings shall be made by a modification to the instant contract in accordance 
with paragraph (h)(5) of this clause. For incentive contracts, shares shall be added as a separate firm-fixed-price line item on the instant contract. The 
Contractor shall maintain records adequate to identify the first delivered unit for 3 years after final payment under this contract.
(2) The Contracting Officer shall calculate the Contractor's share of concurrent contract savings by-
(i) Subtracting from the reduction in price negotiated on the concurrent contract any Government costs or negative instant contract savings not yet 
offset; and
(ii) Multiplying the result by the Contractor's sharing rate.
(3) The Contracting Officer shall calculate the Contractor's share of future contract savings by-
(i) Multiplying the future unit cost reduction by the number of future contract units scheduled for delivery during the sharing period;
(ii) Subtracting any Government costs or negative instant contract savings not yet offset; and
(iii) Multiplying the result by the Contractor's sharing rate.
(4) When the Government wishes and the Contractor agrees, the Contractor's share of future contract savings may be paid in a single lump sum rather 
than in a series of payments over time as future contracts are awarded. Under this alternate procedure, the future contract savings may be calculated 
when the VECP is accepted, on the basis of the Contracting Officer's forecast of the number of units that will be delivered during the sharing period. 
The Contractor's share shall be included in a modification to this contract (see paragraph (h)(3) of this clause) and shall not be subject to subsequent 
adjustment.
(5) Alternate no-cost settlement method. When, in accordance with section 48.104-4 of the Federal Acquisition Regulation (FAR), the Government 
and the Contractor mutually agree to use the no-cost settlement method, the following applies:
(i) The Contractor will keep all the savings on the instant contract and on its concurrent contracts only.
(ii) The Government will keep all the savings resulting from concurrent contracts placed on other sources, savings from all future contracts, and all 
collateral savings.
(j) Collateral savings. If a VECP is accepted, the Contracting Officer will increase the instant contract amount, as specified in paragraph (h)(5) of this 
clause, by a rate from 20 to 100 percent, as determined by the Contracting Officer, of any projected collateral savings determined to be realized in a 
typical year of use after subtracting any Government costs not previously offset. However, the Contractor's share of collateral savings will not exceed 
the contract's firm-fixed-price, target price, target cost, or estimated cost, at the time the VECP is accepted, or $100,000, whichever is greater. The 
Contracting Officer will be the sole determiner of the amount of collateral savings.
(k) Relationship to other incentives. Only those benefits of an accepted VECP not rewardable under performance, design-to-cost (production unit cost, 
operating and support costs, reliability and maintainability), or similar incentives shall be rewarded under this clause. However, the targets of such 
incentives affected by the VECP shall not be adjusted because of VECP acceptance. If this contract specifies targets but provides no incentive to 
surpass them, the value engineering sharing shall apply only to the amount of achievement better than target.
(l) Subcontracts. The Contractor shall include an appropriate value engineering clause in any subcontract-valued at or above the simplified acquisition 
threshold, as defined in FAR 2.101 on the date of subcontract award, and may include one in subcontracts of lesser value. In calculating any 
adjustment in this contract's price for instant contract savings (or negative instant contract savings), the Contractor's allowable development and 
implementation costs shall include any subcontractor's allowable development and implementation costs, and any value engineering incentive 
payments to a subcontractor, clearly resulting from a VECP accepted by the Government under this contract. The Contractor may choose any 
arrangement for subcontractor value engineering incentive payments, provided, that the payments shall not reduce the Government's share of 
concurrent or future contract savings or collateral savings.
(m) Data. The Contractor may restrict the Government's right to use any part of a VECP or the supporting data by marking the following legend on 
the affected parts:
These data, furnished under the Value Engineering clause of contract ____, shall not be disclosed outside the Government or duplicated, used, or 
disclosed, in whole or in part, for any purpose other than to evaluate a value engineering change proposal submitted under the clause. This restriction 
does not limit the Government's right to use information

If a VECP is accepted, the Contractor hereby grants the Government unlimited rights in the VECP and supporting data, except that, with respect to W519TC25RA005Page 54 of 86

252.237-7023 Continuation of Essential Contractor Services. (Oct 2010)
As prescribed in 237.7603(a), use the following clause:
CONTINUATION OF ESSENTIAL CONTRACTOR SERVICES (OCT 2010)
 (a) Definitions. As used in this clause-
 (1) "Essential contractor service" means a service provided by a firm or individual under contract to DoD to support mission-essential functions, such 
as support of vital systems, including ships owned, leased, or operated in support of military missions or roles at sea; associated support activities, 
including installation, garrison, and base support services; and similar services provided to foreign military sales customers under the Security 
Assistance Program. Services are essential if the effectiveness of defense systems or operations has the potential to be seriously impaired by the 
interruption of these services, as determined by the appropriate functional commander or civilian equivalent.
 (2) "Mission-essential functions" means those organizational activities that must be performed under all circumstances to achieve DoD component 
missions or responsibilities, as determined by the appropriate functional commander or civilian equivalent. Failure to perform or sustain these 
functions would significantly affect DoD's ability to provide vital services or exercise authority, direction, and control.
 (b) The Government has identified all or a portion of the contractor services performed under this contract as essential contractor services in support 
of mission essential functions. These services are listed in attachment 0001-0017 PWS 1-17, Mission-Essential Contractor Services, dated ____.
 (c)(1) The Mission-Essential Contractor Services Plan submitted by the Contractor, is incorporated in this contract.
 (2) The Contractor shall maintain and update its plan as necessary. The Contractor shall provide all plan updates to the Contracting Officer for 
approval.
 (3) As directed by the Contracting Officer, the Contractor shall participate in training events, exercises, and drills associated with Government efforts 
to test the effectiveness of continuity of operations procedures and practices.
 (d)(1) Notwithstanding any other clause of this contract, the contractor shall be responsible to perform those services identified as essential contractor 
services during crisis situations (as directed by the Contracting Officer), in accordance with its Mission-Essential Contractor Services Plan.
 (2) In the event the Contractor anticipates not being able to perform any of the essential contractor services identified in accordance with paragraph 
(b) of this section during a crisis situation, the Contractor shall notify the Contracting Officer or other designated representative as expeditiously as 
possible and use its best efforts to cooperate with the Government in the Government's efforts to maintain the continuity of operations.
 (e) The Government reserves the right in such crisis situations to use Federal employees, military personnel or contract support from other 
contractors, or to enter into new contracts for essential contractor services.
 (f) Changes. The Contractor shall segregate and separately identify all costs incurred in continuing performance of essential services in a crisis 
situation. The Contractor shall notify the Contracting Officer of an increase or decrease in costs within ninety days after continued performance has 
been directed by the Contracting Officer, or within any additional period that the Contracting Officer approves in writing, but not later than the date of 
final payment under the contract. The Contractor's notice shall include the Contractor's proposal for an equitable adjustment and any data supporting 
the increase or decrease in the form prescribed by the Contracting Officer. The parties shall negotiate an equitable price adjustment to the contract 
price, delivery schedule, or both as soon as is practicable after receipt of the Contractor's proposal.
 (g) The Contractor shall include the substance of this clause, including this paragraph (g), in subcontracts for the essential services.
(End of clause)
252.239-7016 Telecommunications Security Equipment, Devices, Techniques, and Services. (Dec 1991)
As prescribed in 239.7411(d), use the following clause: W519TC25RA005Page 57 of 86
TELECOMMUNICATIONS SECURITY EQUIPMENT, DEVICES, TECHNIQUES, AND SERVICES (DEC 1991) 
 (a) Definitions. As used in this clause- 
 (1) "Securing" means the application of Government-approved telecommunications security equipment, devices, techniques, or services to contractor 
telecommunications systems. 
 (2) "Sensitive information" means any information the loss, misuse, or modification of which, or unauthorized access to, could adversely affect the 
national interest or the conduct of Federal programs, or the privacy to which individuals are entitled under 5 U.S.C. 552a (the Privacy Act), but which 
has not been specifically authorized under criteria established by an Executive Order or Act of Congress to be kept secret in the interest of national 
defense or foreign policy. 
 (3) "Telecommunications systems" means voice, record, and data communications, including management information systems and local data 
networks that connect to external transmission media, when employed by Government agencies, contractors, and subcontractors to transmit- 
 (i) Classified or sensitive information;

chunk-5b54b0d4fa171b908fceddad0b931f48.content:
a (the Privacy Act), but which 
has not been specifically authorized under criteria established by an Executive Order or Act of Congress to be kept secret in the interest of national 
defense or foreign policy. 
 (3) "Telecommunications systems" means voice, record, and data communications, including management information systems and local data 
networks that connect to external transmission media, when employed by Government agencies, contractors, and subcontractors to transmit- 
 (i) Classified or sensitive information; 
 (ii) Matters involving intelligence activities, cryptologic activities related to national security, the command and control of military forces, or 
equipment that is an integral part of a weapon or weapons system; or 
 (iii) Matters critical to the direct fulfillment of military or intelligence missions. 
 (b) This solicitation/contract identifies classified or sensitive information that requires securing during telecommunications and requires the 
Contractor to secure telecommunications systems. The Contractor agrees to secure information and systems at the following location:Hawthorne 
Army Depot(Identify the location.) 
 (c) To provide the security, the Contractor shall use Government-approved telecommunications equipment, devices, techniques, or services. A list of 
the approved equipment, etc. may be obtained from (identify where list can be obtained). Equipment, devices, techniques, or services used by the 
Contractor must be compatible or interoperable with (list and identify the location of any telecommunications security equipment, device, technique, 
or service currently being used by the technical or requirements organization or other offices with which the Contractor must communicate). 
 (d) Except as may be provided elsewhere in this contract, the Contractor shall furnish all telecommunications security equipment, devices, 
techniques, or services necessary to perform this contract. The Contractor must meet ownership eligibility conditions for communications security 
equipment designated as controlled cryptographic items. 
 (e) The Contractor agrees to include this clause, including this paragraph (e), in all subcontracts which require securing telecommunications. 
(End of clause) W519TC25RA005Page 58 of 86

Section L - Instructions, Conditions, & Notices to Offerors or Quoters
This document incorporates one or more provisions by reference, with the same force and effect as if they were given in full 
text. Upon request, the Contracting Officer will make their full text available. Also, the full text of a provision may be accessed 
electronically at https://www.acquisition.gov/.
If the provision requires additional or unique information, then that information is provided immediately after the provision title.
L.1 GENERAL INSTRUCTIONS
L.1.1 The Offeror's proposal shall be signed and submitted by an individual who has authority on behalf of the Offeror to enter 
into a contract based on the submitted proposal. The Offeror's proposal shall be written in the English language and conform to 
the instructions below.
L.1.2 In accordance with Federal Acquisition Regulation (FAR) 52.215-1Alt I, Instructions to Offerors - Competitive 
Acquisitions (Nov 2021), the Government intends to award after conducting discussions with Offerors in accordance with FAR 
15.306(d). The Government reserves the right to award without conducting discussions should it be determined to be in the 
Government's best interest. It is the Offeror's responsibility to provide current, complete, and accurate information in its 
proposal. The Offeror is cautioned to examine this solicitation in its entirety and to ensure that its proposal contains all necessary 
information, provides all required documentation, and is complete.
L.1.3 For the purposes of evaluation, the term Offeror is defined as the prime Contractor and its participating suppliers/vendors. 
Proposals shall be submitted in accordance with all section L requirements.
L.1.4 For the purpose of evaluation, the Offeror does not need to address each Performance Work Statement (PWS) nor every 
paragraph in any given PWS in the written narrative, unless specifically identified under the associated Factor. However, the 
Offeror will be required to perform all PWSs and all PWSs shall be identified in the Pricing Factor.
L.1.5 Proposal Submission: The Offeror shall submit its proposal to via the PIEE Solicitation Module. The Offeror is 
responsible for submitting the electronic copy of its proposal by the date and time specified in Block 9 of the SF 33. Failure to 
do so will result in the proposal being considered late and treated in accordance with FAR 15.208.
L.1.6 Period for acceptance of offers. The Offeror agrees to hold firm the prices in its offer for 180 calendar days from the date 
specified for receipt of offers. The validity period of the proposal shall be completed by the Offeror on the SF 33 Block 12.
L.1.7 The Government is not under any obligation to correct proposal errors/omissions. Those proposals with errors/omissions, 
where the Government is unable to ascertain the Offeror's intent without discussions or clarifications may be removed from 
further consideration for award. Additionally, the Government reserves the right to reject any proposal that does not comply 
with the instructions in this document as unacceptable, resulting in no further consideration for award.
L.1.8 Each digital submission shall be in Adobe Portable Document Format (PDF), Microsoft (MS) Word, or MS PowerPoint, 
with the exception of the price matrices, Self-Scoring Matrix, and Phase II Maintenance spreadsheet that shall be in the Excel 
templates. Scanned PDF documents must be legible and shall have the ability to be viewed in Adobe Acrobat. The Offeror shall 
not lock or password protect any file.
L.1.9 The Offeror's proposal shall meet the following requirements. Pages shall be 8.5 inches x 11 inches; however, graphs, 
charts, tables and diagrams may use oversized paper of 8.5 inches x 14 inches or 11 inches x 17 inches. Any other page sizes are 
not permitted. Text size shall be no less than 12-point Arial font; however, graphs, charts, tables, and diagrams may use text size 
no less than 8-point Arial Narrow font. All pages shall be numbered and contain at least a one-inch margin.
L.1.10 The Offeror shall acknowledge any amendments issued against this solicitation by signing the Standard Form (SF) 30 
entitled Amendment of Solicitation/Modification of Contract and including it in the proposal submission.
L.1.11 The Government presumes the Offeror's proposal represents its best effort in response to the solicitation. Submissions 
shall be thorough and complete.
L.1.12 The Government

chunk-5656ee1a4a37e47f5ed24f3f764d2ac8.content:
. All pages shall be numbered and contain at least a one-inch margin.
L.1.10 The Offeror shall acknowledge any amendments issued against this solicitation by signing the Standard Form (SF) 30 
entitled Amendment of Solicitation/Modification of Contract and including it in the proposal submission.
L.1.11 The Government presumes the Offeror's proposal represents its best effort in response to the solicitation. Submissions 
shall be thorough and complete.
L.1.12 The Government will use a two-phase approach to proposal evaluation. In Phase I, Offerors' proposals will consist of the 
Technical Experience Self-Scoring Matrix Excel spreadsheet at Attachment 0017, Work Samples, and Project Reference at 
Attachment 0020 for the Maintenance, Demil, SDO, and Small Business Factors. Phase II will include submission of a written 
proposal and spreadsheet for the Maintenance Factor, oral presentations with submission of slides for the Demil and Innovation
/Business Development Factors, and the Price Matrix at Attachments 0018-0019.W519TC25RA005Page 66 of 86
L.1.13 Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools in Proposal Evaluation
L.1.13.1. Use of AI tools in Support of Evaluations: The Government may employ AI as a tool to assist in the analysis and 
review of Offeror proposals. AI tools may be used to support tasks such as summarizing proposal content, identifying 
compliance with request for task order proposal/solicitation requirements, and highlighting areas of potential strength, weakness, 
or risk.
L.1.13.2 Maintaining Inherently Governmental Functions: Notwithstanding the use of AI tools to support the evaluation process, 
all final evaluation judgements, including the assignment or assessment of adjectival ratings, best value determinations, and 
source selection decisions, will be made exclusively by duly appointed Government personnel. The Government retains sole 
responsibility for all inherently governmental functions and will not delegate decision making authority to any AI tool.
L.1.13.3 Offeror Confidentiality and Data Protection: The AI tools utilized by the Government will be employed in a manner 
consistent with applicable regulations that govern the protection of proprietary and source selection sensitive information. The 
AI tool will be an output-only system. Any generated report data is not saved. No proposal data will be transmitted to or 
processed by external, non-Government systems without appropriate safeguards and authorizations in place.
L.2 PHASE I
L.2.1 PHASE I INSTRUCTIONS
L.2.1.1 Offers shall submit a Technical Experience Self-Scoring Matrix with associated Work Samples. Each Work Sample 
shall be include the three-page Project Reference as the first three pages of the Work Sample. Work Samples have no page limit 
and Project References are limited to the three-page template provided. Offerors shall include all information requested on the 
Project Reference Template for each Work Sample submission. Contractual documents submitted in accordance with Factor 1.5 
have no page limit.
L.2.1.2 Offerors shall complete a Project Reference for each Work Sample submitted. Each Project Reference shall include all 
information included in the Project Reference Template at Attachment 20, including the contract/order number and at least two 
Government or customer Points of Contact (POCs). The Government may contact the POCs provided, and reserves the right to 
contact additional POCs as necessary.
L.2.1.3 Offerors shall submit Work Samples (contracts/orders) which demonstrate their technical experience in the required 
categories. Work Samples may count toward multiple categories. Future performance periods on an existing contract do not 
demonstrate technical experience and shall not be utilized as Work Samples, nor be factored into the total point value of a 
submitted sample. An acceptable Work Sample is defined as either an IDIQ contract, non-IDIQ contract, or a task order under 
an IDIQ contract (FAR16.501-1), on which the Offeror performed for at least one year, with that one year taking place within 
the last seven years of the release date of this solicitation. For all current and ongoing Work Samples the Offeror shall calculate 
their points based on data up until proposal submission. Parent, affiliate, and subsidiary organizations as well as Joint Venture 
contracts may utilize data from any company within the organizational structure for Work Sample submissions as long as the 
company was performing as the Prime Contractor on the Work Sample.
L.2.1.4 The Work Samples shall consist of only official contract documentation (including, but not limited to, Performance 
Work Statements (PWSs), Statements of Work (SOWs), Contract Data Requirement Lists (CDRLs), and Invoices). The 
Government will accept a Statement of Fact from the cognizant contracting officer or contracting officer representative (COR) 
to confirm missing information, should contractual documents not carry all the information necessary to substantiate the 
Offeror's scores. The Offeror will need to provide this statement (if needed) and submit as part of its proposal. The Offeror shall 
not create any new documentation (project narratives or project descriptions) outside of the project reference. Where official 
contract documentation is insufficient to substantiate a Self-Rated Score, the Offeror may utilize corporate system reports as 
documentation. When corporate system reports are utilized, the citation must include a signed statement attesting to the validity 
of the reports. Work Samples shall include sufficient information to substantiate each claim. If a Work Sample substantiates 
multiple elements each element must be identified within the Work Sample. The Government reserves the right to ask Offerors 
for clarifications to assist in validation of Self-Rated Scores.
L.2.1.5 Work Samples shall be provided in their original format. Offerors shall used the assigned Work Sample Title provided

chunk-e2ea2de0095afee9beb2ade5631181d0.content:
utilized, the citation must include a signed statement attesting to the validity 
of the reports. Work Samples shall include sufficient information to substantiate each claim. If a Work Sample substantiates 
multiple elements each element must be identified within the Work Sample. The Government reserves the right to ask Offerors 
for clarifications to assist in validation of Self-Rated Scores.
L.2.1.5 Work Samples shall be provided in their original format. Offerors shall used the assigned Work Sample Title provided in 
the Self-Scoring Matrix. All pages of all Work Samples shall be numbered. In addition, the original pagination of each 
document shall be retained. If the original documentation within a Work Sample is not numbered, Offerors shall add page 
numbers. Font, text size, and margin requirements established in Section L.1 General Instructions do not apply to Work Sample 
submissions. All Work Sample submissions shall be in English. If more than one document is provided as part of a Work 
Sample, the documents shall be combined as one file and numbered accordingly. Offerors shall include all documentation for a 
given Work Sample in a single PDF file and add to each page the unique Work Sample Title identified on the Self-Scoring W519TC25RA005Page 67 of 86
Matrix and page number in the margin. While this consolidation and notation may result in some confusion (such as multiple 
pages identified as "page 1" if the citation includes page 1 of an SF33/SF1449/DD1155, page 1 of the PWS, etc.), the result will 
ensure that Government evaluators can find all documentation quickly and efficiently.
L.2.1.6 Work Samples Qualifications: All Work Samples shall meet these minimum qualifications (unless otherwise provided 
for per criteria).
L.2.1.6.1 Shall be performed or ongoing within the last seven years from the date of issuance of this solicitation and performed 
for a minimum of one year.
L.2.1.6.2 Offerors shall identify what company will be performing the identified PWS work if awarded the Hawthorne Army 
Depot contract and all Work Samples shall represent work previously done by that contractor or subcontractor. If subcontractor 
Work Samples are used, the Offeror shall submit letters of commitment from the subcontractor(s).
L.2.1.6.3 Work Samples shall fall into one of the following categories. Project References shall identify if the Work Sample is 
from the Prime contractor or Subcontractor.
L.2.1.6.3.1 Category 1: Prime Offeror Work Samples. In order to be used, the Offeror shall have acted as the Prime or first tier 
subcontractor, which may include work performed as part of a joint venture. If a company establishes a joint venture for this 
contract, work of both prime companies may be utilized. Primes may also include subsidiaries or legal entities which fall under 
the parent corporation. In order to use a subsidiary or legal entity as a prime Work Sample, the acquisition of the subsidiary or 
legal entity shall have been finalized as of the date of initial RFP issuance of this solicitation, and objective evidence shall be 
included in the Work Sample to demonstrate that they are now a legal entity of the corporation. If an Offeror wants to rely on an 
affiliate's past experience, then the Offeror must show how that subsidiary's workforce, management, facilities, or other 
resources will affect contract performance. If these criteria are met, subsidiary or legal entity Work Samples will be considered 
prime Work Samples, even if the work occurred prior to the company being acquired.
L.2.1.6.3.2 Category 2: Subcontractor Work Samples. In order to be used, the Offeror shall:
(1) Identify which subcontractor will be performing the identified PWS work if awarded the Hawthorne Army Depot 
contract and all Work Samples shall represent work previously done by that subcontractor;
(2) Submit letters of commitment from subcontractor(s); and
(3) Have acted as the prime or first tier subcontractor on the contract or order submitted.
L.2.1.6.4 Shall include at least one year of performance within the last seven years from the date of RFP issuance. For Work 
Samples where all periods of performance (PoP) do not meet this qualification (such as Base Year PoP outside the seven-year 
limitation and an Option Year PoP within the limitation), only the PoP which meet this criterion shall be utilized for scoring 
purposes.
L.2.1.6.5 Work Samples that do not satisfy the minimum requirements described in L.2.1.6 will not be further evaluated by the 
Government to validate the associated Self-Rated Score.
L.2.2 FACTOR 1.1 MAINTENANCE 
L.2.2.1 Maintenance Factor Work Sample Definitions and Proposal Requirements
L.2.2.1.1 Definition: Facilities are defined as buildings, structures, and linear structure improvements and additions.
A building is defined as an enclosed structure with a roof and walls, usually standing permanently in one place. Mobile 
structures are defined under equipment.
L.2.2.1.2 Proposal Requirements: The Offeror shall identify the company that will be performing Maintenance work if awarded 
the Hawthorne Army Depot contract and all Work Samples shall represent work done by that company. This company's name 
should be the name provided for entry five of the Project Reference. Offerors shall submit letters of commitment from 
subcontractors, if subcontractor Work Samples are used for this factor. The Offeror shall have performed the work in the Work 
Sample for at least one year, with that one year taking place within the last seven years of the release date of this solicitation.

L.2.2.5 Number of Consecutive Years the Offeror Performed Facility Maintenance Work
L.2.2.5.1 Definition: Facility Maintenance Work is defined as performing maintenance that requires the use of a minimum of 10

L.2.2.7 Number of Pieces of Equipment Maintained Under a Single Contract/Task Order
L.2.2.7.1 Definition: Equipment includes assets of installed building equipment and industrial machinery and equipment that is a 
tangible item that is functionally complete for its intended purpose, durable, nonexpendable, and needed for the performance of 
a contract. Equipment is not intended for sale and does not ordinarily lose its identity or become a component part of another 
article when put into use. Equipment does not include material, real property, special test equipment or special tooling. 
Installed building equipment is defined as equipment affixed to or built into a facility that is an integral part of the facility.
L.2.2.7.2 Proposal Requirements: Submissions shall include a report that shows the listing of the equipment maintained; 
maintenance requirements in the PWS/SOW; and contract language that makes this Work Sample relevant.
L.2.2.8 Contractor Performance Assessment Reporting System (CPARS)
L.2.2.8.1 Definition: CPARS ratings will be calculated by taking the average of the Offeror's Quality, Schedule, and 
Management scores using the values below. If no rating is provided in any of the 3 categories (Quality, Schedule, and 
Management) a score of neutral (750) will be applied to that category. The calculated average will be rounded to the nearest 
whole number to determine the Offeror's score.
Exceptional Rating = 1000 points
Very Good Rating = 900 points
Satisfactory/Neutral Rating = 750 points
Marginal Rating = 500 points
Unsatisfactory Rating = 0 points
L.2.2.8.2 Proposal Requirements: CPARS submissions shall be for the contracts submitted for the three maintenance Work 
Samples under L.2.2.2. If CPARS ratings were received at the level of Work Sample submission (contract, IDIQ contract, or 
task order), CPARS Work Samples shall be the most recent ratings received for that Work Sample. If CPARS ratings were 
received only at the IDIQ level and a task order under an IDIQ is submitted for a Work Sample, then CPARS Work Samples 
shall be from the same year as the task order Work Sample. If any of the Offeror's Work Samples do not have CPARS ratings, W519TC25RA005Page 69 of 86
the Government will assign a score of Satisfactory/Neutral for that Work Sample Performance Related Experience. Offerors are 
encouraged to address any adverse past performance, including corrective actions, in their CPARS Work Sample Project 
References.

L.2.5 FACTOR 1.4: SMALL BUSINESS
L.2.5.1 Small Business Factor Work Sample Definitions and Proposal Requirements L.2.5.1.1 Definition: Small business 
categories considered will include overall small business concerns, small disadvantaged business concerns, women-owned small 
business concerns, HUBZone small business concerns, and service-disabled veteran-owned small business concerns.
L.2.5.1.2 Proposal Requirements: Small business Work Samples shall be for the prime Offeror only. This Requirement applies 
to other than Small Business Prime Offerors only. Small business Prime Offerors will be given the maximum score.
L.2.5.2 Number of Small Business Categories Met or Exceeded
L.2.5.2.1 Definition: Total number of small business categories each Work Sample shows the Offeror met or exceeded. Small 
business categories include overall small business concerns, women-owned small business concerns, HUBZone small business 
concerns, and service-disabled veteran-owned small business concerns.
L.2.5.2.2 Proposal Requirements: Offerors shall submit three Individual Subcontracting Report (ISR) or Summary Subcontract 
Report (SSR) samples where work was performed within the last five years prior to the solicitation release date.
L.2.6 FACTOR 1.5: CONTRACTUAL DOCUMENTS
L.2.6.1 Offerors shall submit a complete and signed SF33 and SF30 if amendments are issued.
L.2.6.2 Offerors shall submit Section K Representations, Certifications, and Other Statement of Offerors; Property Management 
Plan; Small Business Subcontracting Plan; clause fill-ins for all sections of the solicitation; subcontractor letters of commitment 
(for all subcontractors where subcontractor Work Samples were provided in support of Self-Scoring Matrix scores); and a small 
business size standard certification and/or joint venture or partnership agreement (if applicable).
L.3 PHASE II
L.3.1 PHASE II INSTRUCTIONS
L.3.1.1 All Offerors who submit a Phase I proposal that meets all minimum requirements described in Phase I will be given 20 
days from notification to submit all Factors described in Phase II. All Offerors who submit a Phase I proposal that does not meet 
all minimum requirements described in Phase I will be notified of their removal from further consideration for award. Offeror's 
Phase I scores will only be used to validate they have met the 60,000 point threshold. Offeror's Phase I scores will not be used in 
any portion of Phase II, including the best value tradeoff decision.W519TC25RA005Page 72 of 86
L.3.1.2 The Government will conduct Phase II evaluations using the best value trade-off approach and in accordance with 
Section M. The relative order of importance assigned to the evaluation Factors is: the Maintenance Factor is the most important 
Factor, the Demil and Innovation/Business Development Factors are of equal importance, followed by the Price Factor. All non-
price Factors, when combined, are significantly more important than price.
L.3.1.3 All pages of each factor shall be appropriately numbered and identified with the company name, date, proposal factor 
number, and solicitation number in the header and/or footer. A working electronic table of contents/index and a list of acronyms 
may be included for each factor.
L.3.1.4 The Offeror's slides shall meet the following requirements. Text size shall be no less than 12-point Arial font and there 
shall be a maximum of ten bullets per slide. Black and white or color is permitted, and graphics are permitted. Slides shall be 
sequentially numbered. Offeror's may use embedded videos in oral presentations. However, videos shall be played during the 
presentation in order to be used for evaluation purposes and will be included in the allotted time limit for presentations.
L.3.1.5 Page Limitations: The Government will not read or evaluate pages exceeding the below prescribed limitations; excess 
pages will be removed and not considered. Page limitations do not include table of contents, cross reference matrices, indices, 
glossaries, or acronym lists. No material may be incorporated in the proposal by reference, attachment, appendix, videotape, 
audiotape or other electronic media as a means to circumvent the page limitation. No electronic video or audio material will be 
reviewed or considered in the evaluation. Files shall not contain classified data. The use of hyperlinks in proposals is prohibited.

L.3.1.6 Oral Presentations
L.3.1.6.1 In lieu of written proposals for Factors 2.2 Demil and 2.3 Innovation/Business Development, the Offeror's will be 
required to submit slides and give oral presentations.
L.3.1.6.2 At the conclusion of each Offeror's oral presentation, the Government personnel will briefly caucus for up to an hour 
to determine if any clarifications of the Offeror's presentation are required. If the Government determines there is a need for 
clarifications, all clarifications will be provided in writing to the Offeror. The Offeror will be provided up to an hour to respond 
verbally, as well as in writing, with the appropriate answers that directly address the questions asked by the Government.W519TC25RA005Page 73 of 86
L.3.1.6.3 The oral presentations may be recorded. Participants may take notes, but no official transcript of the oral presentations 
will be made. The Offerors must provide written consent to record. Recording will be limited to the Government only and the 
Offeror may not record the oral presentations.
L.3.1.6.4 It is recommended, the Offeror's key personnel who will perform or personally direct the work being described 
conduct their relevant portions of the presentations. Key personnel include project managers, task leaders, and other in-house 
staff of the Offeror. Subcontractors can be utilized as presenters at the Offeror's discretion. The names of presenters shall be 
listed on the Title Slide for each Volume. Offerors are permitted to have up to two non-presenters in the room during the 
presentation.
L.3.1.6.5 If there are any inconsistencies between the slides and oral presentations, the Government will attempt to address those 
issues during the clarification period held after the oral presentation. However, the Government reserves the right, as noted 
above, to conduct discussions to resolve any inconsistencies. Offerors shall ensure that all key factual information (such as dates, 
quantities, product numbers, etc.) are included in the slides to reduce the chances that information will be missed during the oral 
presentation.
L.3.1.6.6 The oral presentation will not become a part of any contract resulting from this RFP but will be evaluated for purposes 
of award decision. The oral presentations and the same-day clarifications will not constitute discussions, as defined in FAR 
15.306(d), nor will it obligate the Government to conduct discussions or to solicit or entertain any proposal revisions.
L.3.1.6.7 The Procuring Contracting Officer will schedule the oral presentations and will notify each Offeror of the date, time 
and location of its oral presentation after the Government receives the proposals in response to this RFP. The order in which 
Offerors will make its presentations will be determined by the drawing of lots by the Procuring Contracting Officer. Oral 
presentations will be scheduled no sooner than five working days after closing date of the RFP. Each Offeror will be notified, in 
writing with acknowledgement requested, of the scheduled date and time for the presentations. The Government reserves the 
right to reschedule presentations at the sole discretion of the Procuring Contracting Officer. Once notified of the scheduled 
presentation date and time, each Offeror shall complete the presentation at that scheduled date and time.
L.3.1.6.8 The facilities available for use by Offerors are limited to a conference room and overhead images (slides) via 
electronic projection. The Government will provide all facilities.
L.3.1.6.9 The oral presentation's specific location will be determined after the closing of the RFP. Presentations will be 
conducted at Rock Island Arsenal in Rock Island, IL.
L.3.1.6.10 The U.S. Government will not pay for or reimburse any Offerors for cost associated with oral presentations.
L.3.1.7 The Offeror is expected to provide sufficient detail in a clear, concise, organized and complete manner to completely and 
logically address each evaluation factor. Deficiencies, whether informational or technical, may be cause for elimination from the 
competitive range and/or rejection of the offer. Unsupported promises to comply with the contractual requirements are not 
sufficient. Proposal shall not merely reiterate the contractual specifications but rather provide convincing documentary evidence 
of how contract requirements will be met. Proprietary information shall be clearly marked.
L.3.1.8 The successful Offeror's proposal may be incorporated into the resultant contract in whole or in part, at the discretion of 
the Government, at the time of award.
L.3.2 FACTOR 2.1: MAINTENANCE
L.3.2.1 This Factor shall be limited to 25 pages for the maintenance plan with an additional Excel spreadsheet that includes 
contractor selected maintenance activities for the assets of the three buildings identified below.
L.3.2.2 The Offeror shall propose detailed Maintenance Plans for three buildings, (1) Dock 3, (2) 117-6 North Tower, and (3)

chunk-3f970e3e0d5c3ef0ee8a31242777b4cc.content:
.3.2 FACTOR 2.1: MAINTENANCE
L.3.2.1 This Factor shall be limited to 25 pages for the maintenance plan with an additional Excel spreadsheet that includes 
contractor selected maintenance activities for the assets of the three buildings identified below.
L.3.2.2 The Offeror shall propose detailed Maintenance Plans for three buildings, (1) Dock 3, (2) 117-6 North Tower, and (3) 
Building 3, in accordance with the requirements of the Maintenance PWS. Each building's maintenance plan shall describe, at 
the appropriate level of detail, all information and steps for how the Offeror would maintain the three buildings listed, to 
include, but not limited to, real property, installed building equipment, and personal property.
L.3.2.2.1 The Offeror shall include a narrative describing the work to be done, frequencies, annual labor hours, and assumptions 
made to arrive at these planned labor hours. The Offeror shall show a breakout of the labor category and associated hours, as 
well as identify and quantify any materials and equipment needed to meet the requirements of each section of the Maintenance 
PWS.
L.3.2.2.2 The Offeror shall provide workforce skillsets and credentials required of Contractor personnel supporting and 
performing work to meet the requirements of the Maintenance PWS, e.g., licenses, certifications, etc. The Offeror shall identify W519TC25RA005Page 74 of 86
whether each skillset will include dedicated onsite employees, subcontractors, or other arrangements, and shall describe the 
availability, location, and degree each skillset is allocated to each section of the Maintenance PWS. The Offeror shall identify 
predominant skillsets needed to support and perform the requirements within each section of the Maintenance PWS.
L.3.2.2.3 The Offeror's proposal shall include innovative processes, as applicable. Innovation is defined as providing efficiencies 
in cost, schedule, and/or quality while still meeting all requirements of the Maintenance PWS.
L.3.2.2.4 Asset List Spreadsheet: Offerors shall outline a complete list of all planned maintenance activities to be completed in a 
year for each building. The spreadsheet shall be limited to no more than 15 columns and include, at a minimum, the columns 
listed below:
Building Number: 117-6N, Building 3, or Dock 3
Asset Identification: HWAD asset number or an Offeror created number
Asset Description: Make, model, serial number (if available) or simple description of the asset
Maintenance Task Type: The type of maintenance task to be completed (Inspection, Preventative, Predictive, etc.)
Maintenance Task Description: Description of what is to be completed
Frequency of Task: Description of how often task will be completed
L.3.3 FACTOR 2.2: DEMIL
L.3.3.1 The Offeror shall submit a detailed Demil Plan for each of the four MIDAS families in the MGQ, covering Demil, 
treatment, and disposal operations. This Factor shall be limited to 40 slides and a two-hour oral presentation.
The Minimum Guaranteed Quantity (MGQ) includes:
i. DODIC: D561/D562 MIDAS: HIIM Nomenclature: PROJ, 155MM HE APERS M449 Short Tons: 1,000
ii. DODIC: E890/E891/E850 MIDAS: HICC Nomenclature: DISP & BOMB, ACFT CBU 87 Short Tons: 1,000
iii. DODIC: Various MIDAS: SAO Nomenclature: Small Arms (5.56mm and 7.62mm) Short Tons: 50
iv. DODIC: Various MIDAS: HBD Nomenclature: General Purpose Bombs Short Tons: 634
L.3.3.2 Technical Approach: Each Demil Plan shall detail how the Offeror will accomplish Demil, treatment, and disposal, 
including facilitation, permitting, equipment, personnel, critical operations, waste streams, and risk management. Clearly mark 
each section with the applicable MIDAS family and include innovative practices, where applicable.
L.3.3.2.1 Demil Rate: Provide a projected monthly Demil rate demonstrating the Offeror's capacity to efficiently demil the 
MGQ.
L.3.3.2.2. Subcontractors: Identify all major/key subcontractors providing critical Demil services (those involving energetic 
materials, sensitive components, or hazardous waste).
L.3.3.2.3 Waste Management: Detail a plan for anticipated residual and unsalvageable material, including identification of all 
waste streams for each MIDAS family.
L.3.3.2.4 Open Burn/Open Detonation (OB/OD): If OB/OD is required for any MIDAS family, provide a specific plan detailing 
experience, knowledge, capabilities, and key personnel/positions.
L.3.3.2.5 Quality Management System (QMS): Describe the Offeror's approach to meeting quality requirements, including 
identification of the QMS to be used. Specify whether or not it is certified or equivalent with Industry Standards, such as ISO 
9001, or equivalent system acceptable to the Government. The Offeror shall describe its system in sufficient detail to determine 
its suitability for use in performing the resultant contract, particularly if it is an equivalent system. If the Offeror does not have a 
QMS in place at the time of contract award or is planning on updating from a previous version of the QMS standard, a Quality 
Assurance Project Plan (QAPP) with a Plan of Action and Milestones

chunk-c640759830ad9c3b191d7d5d2776388b.content:
, such as ISO 
9001, or equivalent system acceptable to the Government. The Offeror shall describe its system in sufficient detail to determine 
its suitability for use in performing the resultant contract, particularly if it is an equivalent system. If the Offeror does not have a 
QMS in place at the time of contract award or is planning on updating from a previous version of the QMS standard, a Quality 
Assurance Project Plan (QAPP) with a Plan of Action and Milestones (PoAM) shall be submitted. The Offeror shall provide 
proof of certification, if any.
L.3.3.6 Demil Management:
L.3.3.6.1 Organizational Structure: Describe the organizational structure, disciplines, responsibilities, experience, and expertise 
for accomplishing the requirements. Clearly define the relationship between the program and higher-level management, 
reporting responsibilities, lines of authority, communication processes with the Government team (Administrative Contracting W519TC25RA005Page 75 of 86
Officer and Quality Assurance Specialist Ammunition Surveillance Chief of Demil), and the relationship with subcontractors. 
Identify the Demil Manager and describe their duties.
L.3.3.6.2 Risk Management Plan (RMP): Include an RMP identifying programmatic risks (cost, schedule, technical), mitigation 
strategies, and a continuous review process. Describe how risks will be identified, mitigated, and managed, including an incident 
response plan. It shall include what the Offeror considers to be its initial significant risk areas and the Offeror's initial plans for 
mitigating those risks.
L.3.4 FACTOR 2.3: INNOVATION/BUSINESS DEVELOPMENT
L.3.4.1 This Factor shall be limited to 25 slides and a one-hour oral presentation. The Offeror shall submit a detailed marketing 
and business development plan for HWAD that incorporates innovative strategies to revitalize the site, attract new businesses, 
and drive down costs. The plan must include the following:
L.3.4.1.1 A Target Market Analysis and justification used to identify specific industries and businesses best suited for HWAD.
L.3.4.1.2 A Value Proposition that will be used to attract target industries to HWAD.
L.3.4.1.3 A description of the market strategies to be used by the Offeror to get the attention of the target markets. The 
contractor shall detail proposed marketing channels, budget allocation, and key performance indicators. The Contractor must 
present this from the perspective of a potential investor, not simply a list of features.
L.3.4.1.4 A description of how the Offeror plans to differentiate HWAD from other relocations sites.
L.3.4.1.5 A Sustainability Plan to explain how the Offer will ensure the marketing plan continues to contribute to sustainable 
development strategies at HWAD.
L.3.4.2 Implementation & Cost Reduction Strategies (Integrated within Marketing and Business Development Plan): The 
Offeror's Marketing and Business Development Plan shall describe cost reduction strategies and implementation plans. The 
Offeror must provide detailed approaches in the plan for following elements:
L.3.4.2.1 Commercial Facility Utilization
L.3.4.2.2 Small Business Opportunities
L.3.4.2.3 Workforce Development
L.3.4.2.4 Innovative Business Practices
L.3.4.2.5 Market Responsiveness
L.3.4.2.6 Government Cost Reduction
L.3.4.2.7 Product/Service Cost Reduction
L.3.4.2.8 Private Investment Leveraging
L.3.4.2.9 Collaborative Partnerships
L.3.4.2.10 Asset Disposal Mitigation
L.3.5 FACTOR 2.4: PRICE
L.3.5.1 Price Factor Requirements
L.3.5.1.1 Offerors shall submit Attachments 0018 and 0019 without macros.
L.3.5.1.2 Refer to solicitation, Section A, for additional information that may impact proposed unit prices. Proposed firm-fixed 
unit prices are limited to two decimal places. The proposed firm-fixed unit prices shall be the prices used by the Government to 
calculate the evaluated total price and for issuance of task and delivery orders. Offerors must propose unit prices for all quantity 
ranges for each service and each ordering period identified in the Hawthorne Army Depot Price Matrix at Attachment 0018 and 
0019. Failure to comply with the above requirements may result in the proposal being rejected.
L.3.5.1.3 All prices for this acquisition shall be stated in current U.S. dollars and cents for all ordering periods listed in the Price 
Matrix.W519TC25RA005Page 76 of 86
L.3.5.2 The proposal shall consist of:
L.3.5.2.1 An electronic copy in Microsoft Excel of the completed Price Matrix (Attachments 0018 and 0019).
L.3.5.2.2 An addendum to explain any assumptions or other additional information considered necessary to explain the proposed 
pricing.
L.3.5.3 Instructions for completion of the Price Matrix (Attachment 0018) and Minimum Guaranteed Quantity (Attachment 
0019):
L.3.5.3.1 All information to be filled in by the Offeror is highlighted in the Price Matrix in blue.
L.3.5.3.2 The Offeror shall enter its full name in the space provided.
L.3.5.3.3 The Offeror shall enter unit prices for each range in the spaces provided for Contractor fill-in. Each range and weight 
shown applies to all 10 ordering periods

chunk-6d6309b2ab55b825d80d655a6bfb6796.content:
Minimum Guaranteed Quantity (Attachment 
0019):
L.3.5.3.1 All information to be filled in by the Offeror is highlighted in the Price Matrix in blue.
L.3.5.3.2 The Offeror shall enter its full name in the space provided.
L.3.5.3.3 The Offeror shall enter unit prices for each range in the spaces provided for Contractor fill-in. Each range and weight 
shown applies to all 10 ordering periods.
L.3.5.3.4 The Offeror shall propose a Contract Line Item Number (CLIN) price under the minimum guaranteed quantity for each 
listed MIDAS family. The minimum guaranteed quantity will not be included in the total evaluated price.
L.3.5.3.5 For each of the 16 firm-fixed price efforts (PWS CLINs 0001, 0003-0016 and Demil CLIN 0002) identified on the 
Pricing Matrix at Attachment 0018, the Offeror shall provide an adequate and complete breakdown of labor, including all labor 
categories, full time equivalents, total hours, and labor rates for the prime Contractor and all subcontractors. This breakdown 
shall be adequate to support and define all labor, G&A, and fringe included in the Offeror's proposal for all Ordering Periods. 
This information is requested in order to expedite Service Contract Act (SCA) adjustments. This contract contains Collective 
Bargaining Agreements (CBA) with The Operating Engineers Local Union No.3 and The Security Police and Fire Professionals 
of America, which are used by the Department of Labor to generate the CBA Wage Determination which is used for (SCA) 
Price Adjustment Claims for this contract.
L.3.5.3.6 No other information is to be added to the Price Matrix, nor shall Offerors make any changes to the Price Matrix. The 
Price Matrix will be locked to prevent inadvertent changes to the Price Matrix by the Offeror. The Offeror shall not provide 
linked content within the price factor. Price factors that include linked content will be deemed non-compliant and may be 
removed from further consideration for award.
